title: Functional Movement Disorder (FMD)
icd10: ** F44.4 (Conversion disorder with motor symptom or deficit)
scope: ** Evaluation and management of functional (psychogenic) movement disorders including functional tremor, functional dystonia, functional myoclonus, functional parkinsonism, and functional gait disorder. Covers positive diagnostic signs, electrophysiologic confirmation, multidisciplinary treatment. Complements existing FND plan (general) with movement-specific focus. For functional seizures (PNES), see FND general plan. For organic movement disorders, see specific disorder templates (Essential Tremor, Parkinson Disease, Dystonia). For general FND overview, see Functional Neurological Disorder plan.

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Baseline; rule out infection or systemic illness as contributor to neurological symptoms
Metabolic encephalopathy screen; electrolyte derangement as mimic; hepatic dysfunction (Wilson disease screening)
Thyroid dysfunction as contributor to tremor, fatigue, and neuropsychiatric symptoms
Hypoglycemia as mimic of acute neurological symptoms
Inflammatory or autoimmune screen when systemic disease suspected
Inflammatory screen; elevated in systemic inflammatory conditions mimicking movement disorder
UTI screen (delirium/encephalopathy mimic); drug screen component

Extended Workup (Context-Dependent).rationale: Wilson disease screen if young-onset (<50 years) movement disorder; especially if dystonia or tremor
Confirmatory for Wilson disease if ceruloplasmin borderline or low
B12 deficiency neuropathy or myelopathy as comorbidity contributing to gait dysfunction
Deficiency associated with chronic pain and fatigue, common FMD comorbidities
Substance-related movement disorder mimic; psychiatric differential
Autoimmune screen if features suggest SLE or other connective tissue disease
Hashimoto encephalopathy if cognitive or psychiatric features prominent
Iron deficiency as contributor to restless legs syndrome mimic; low ferritin in some movement disorders
Diabetic neuropathy comorbidity contributing to gait difficulty

Rare/Specialized.item: Genetic testing for hereditary dystonia (DYT genes: DYT1/TOR1A, DYT6/THAP1, DYT11/SGCE)
Rare/Specialized.rationale: If functional dystonia features overlap with hereditary dystonia in young patients

Rare/Specialized.item: Huntington disease genetic testing (HTT CAG repeats)
Rare/Specialized.rationale: If chorea component or family history of HD

Rare/Specialized.item: Paraneoplastic antibody panel (CV2, amphiphysin, CASPR2, LGI1)
Rare/Specialized.rationale: If subacute movement disorder with atypical features or cancer risk factors

Rare/Specialized.item: Autoimmune encephalitis antibody panel (serum and CSF)
Rare/Specialized.rationale: If acute/subacute onset with psychiatric features; consider anti-NMDAR encephalitis
If parkinsonism with history of liver disease, TPN, or occupational exposure
If progressive cerebellar ataxia features combined with movement disorder

Essential/First-line.item: MRI brain with and without contrast (CPT 70553)
Essential/First-line.timing: Within 1-2 weeks; URGENT if acute stroke concern
Essential/First-line.target: Normal; rules out structural pathology (basal ganglia lesion, demyelination, mass); provides reassurance data

Essential/First-line.timing: ED triage if acute presentation or head trauma
Essential/First-line.target: Rule out hemorrhage, mass, acute hydrocephalus

Essential/First-line.timing: If tremor is primary presentation; provides objective electrophysiologic evidence
Essential/First-line.target: Variable frequency (>1 Hz variation); entrainment on tapping task; pause with contralateral ballistic movement (evidence of functional tremor)

Extended.timing: If differentiating functional parkinsonism from neurodegenerative parkinsonism
Extended.target: Normal uptake in functional parkinsonism; reduced uptake in Parkinson disease, MSA, PSP

Extended.timing: If peripheral neuropathy or myopathy suspected as comorbidity; helps differentiate organic from functional weakness
Extended.target: Normal or shows functional patterns (inconsistent recruitment, give-way pattern); rules out neuropathy/myopathy

Extended.timing: If myelopathy symptoms or upper motor neuron signs on examination suggest spinal cord pathology
If functional myoclonus suspected; differentiates cortical from functional myoclonus
Extended.target: No pre-movement cortical potential (Bereitschaftspotential) in functional myoclonus; positive Bereitschaftspotential suggests functional origin; cortical correlate present in cortical myoclonus

Extended.timing: If myoclonus evaluation; functional vs cortical vs subcortical differentiation
Extended.target: Absent cortical reflex response supports functional myoclonus

Extended.timing: If comorbid functional seizures suspected alongside movement disorder
Extended.target: Normal EEG during typical event confirms functional origin

Rare/Specialized.timing: If functional cognitive disorder or atypical parkinsonism differential
Rare/Specialized.target: Normal metabolism in FMD; hypometabolism in neurodegenerative parkinsonism

Rare/Specialized.timing: Research/specialized centers; motor cortex excitability assessment
Rare/Specialized.target: Altered cortical inhibition patterns described in FMD (research setting)

Rare/Specialized.timing: Research setting only; not standard clinical use
Rare/Specialized.target: Altered connectivity in motor planning areas; abnormal amygdala activation

Acute/Emergent.item: Verbal de-escalation and reassurance (first-line acute management)
Acute/Emergent.indication: Acute functional movement event (severe tremor, dystonic episode, functional gait failure, functional jerks) in ED or inpatient

doseOptions.orderSentence: Verbal de-escalation and reassurance (first-line acute management) N/A -

dosing.instructions: Use calm, reassuring voice; "I can see your body is doing something involuntary -- I'm going to help you"; grounding techniques (5-4-3-2-1 sensory grounding); do NOT restrain; do NOT use forceful commands
dosing.orderSentence: Verbal de-escalation and reassurance (first-line acute management) N/A -

Acute/Emergent.monitoring: Event duration; response to verbal cues; vital signs; injury assessment

Acute/Emergent.indication: Functional tremor, dystonia, or gait failure during acute presentation; can rapidly demonstrate diagnosis

dosing.instructions: Ask patient to perform contralateral rhythmic tapping (tremor entrainment test); ask patient to walk backward (gait improvement = positive sign); use cognitive loading (serial 7s, word generation) during movement testing

Acute/Emergent.monitoring: Observe for movement normalization with distraction; document positive signs

Acute/Emergent.indication: Do NOT sedate patients with functional movement events; sedation delays diagnosis and causes iatrogenic harm

dosing.instructions: Withhold IV benzodiazepines, haloperidol, or propofol for functional movement events unless diagnostic uncertainty requires emergent treatment of possible organic movement disorder emergency (e.g., status dystonicus)

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: If organic movement disorder emergency cannot be excluded, treat as organic
Acute/Emergent.monitoring: Respiratory status; mental status; document clinical features

Acute/Emergent.item: Lorazepam (ONLY if organic movement disorder emergency cannot be excluded)
Acute/Emergent.indication: Status dystonicus or acute dystonic reaction cannot be excluded; diagnostic uncertainty

doseOptions.orderSentence: Lorazepam (ONLY if organic movement disorder emergency cannot be excluded) 1 mg IV

dosing.instructions: 1-2 mg IV push; may repeat x1 in 10 min; max 4 mg; ONLY if organic dystonic emergency suspected; discontinue once functional diagnosis confirmed
dosing.orderSentence: Lorazepam (ONLY if organic movement disorder emergency cannot be excluded) 1 mg IV

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: Respiratory depression; severe COPD without ventilatory support

Acute/Emergent.item: Diphenhydramine (ONLY if acute dystonic reaction suspected)
Acute/Emergent.indication: Acute dystonic reaction from neuroleptic cannot be excluded as cause

doseOptions.orderSentence: Diphenhydramine (ONLY if acute dystonic reaction suspected) 50 mg IV

dosing.instructions: 50 mg IV/IM x1; response within 15-30 min confirms drug-induced dystonic reaction; if no response, reassess diagnosis
dosing.orderSentence: Diphenhydramine (ONLY if acute dystonic reaction suspected) 50 mg IV

Acute/Emergent.monitoring: Response to treatment; anticholinergic effects; sedation

Diagnosis Delivery and Communication (Co.indication: All FMD patients; THE single most important therapeutic intervention for functional movement disorder

dosing.instructions: Explain FMD as a REAL neurological condition; the nervous system is sending wrong movement signals ("software problem, not hardware"); SHOW the patient their positive signs (entrainment, Hoover sign, distractibility) as EVIDENCE; express confidence in diagnosis; emphasize treatability; direct to www.neurosymptoms.org; allow time for questions

Diagnosis Delivery and Communication (Co.monitoring: Patient understanding; emotional response; acceptance of diagnosis; therapeutic alliance

Diagnosis Delivery and Communication (Co.item: Movement-specific positive sign demonstration to patient
Diagnosis Delivery and Communication (Co.indication: Functional tremor, dystonia, myoclonus, parkinsonism, or gait disorder with identifiable positive signs on examination

doseOptions.orderSentence: Movement-specific positive sign demonstration to patient N/A -

dosing.instructions: For tremor: show patient how tremor changes with contralateral tapping (entrainment); for weakness: demonstrate Hoover sign at bedside; for gait: show improvement with backward walking; for myoclonus: show distractibility of jerks; explain "your brain CAN produce normal movement -- we just saw it"
dosing.orderSentence: Movement-specific positive sign demonstration to patient N/A -

Physical Rehabilitation (Primary Treatme.indication: Functional motor symptoms (tremor, dystonia, weakness, gait disorder); PRIMARY treatment modality with strongest evidence

doseOptions.orderSentence: FMD-specialized physiotherapy (consensus-based approach) Outpatient: 1-2 sessions/week x 12-20 weeks -

dosing.instructions: Movement retraining using distraction techniques; task-specific training; graded exposure to avoided movements; normalize automatic movement patterns; NOT standard strengthening exercises; requires therapist with FMD/FND training (Nielsen consensus approach)
dosing.orderSentence: FMD-specialized physiotherapy (consensus-based approach) Outpatient: 1-2 sessions/week x 12-20 weeks -

Physical Rehabilitation (Primary Treatme.contraindications: Active psychosis; complete refusal to engage
Physical Rehabilitation (Primary Treatme.monitoring: Functional outcome measures (timed 25-foot walk, 10-meter walk test, Berg Balance Scale, tremor rating scale); patient engagement; symptom trajectory

Physical Rehabilitation (Primary Treatme.indication: Severe functional disability not improving with outpatient therapy; wheelchair-bound from functional gait disorder; severe functional dystonia limiting ADLs

doseOptions.orderSentence: Intensive inpatient FMD rehabilitation program 2-5 sessions/day x 3-5 weeks -

dosing.instructions: Intensive multidisciplinary inpatient program with PT, OT, psychology, neurology; consensus-based goal-oriented approach; daily movement retraining with graduated functional challenges
dosing.orderSentence: Intensive inpatient FMD rehabilitation program 2-5 sessions/day x 3-5 weeks -

Physical Rehabilitation (Primary Treatme.contraindications: Severe untreated psychiatric comorbidity; active suicidality; complete lack of engagement
Physical Rehabilitation (Primary Treatme.monitoring: Daily functional outcome measures; goal attainment scaling; discharge readiness

Physical Rehabilitation (Primary Treatme.indication: Upper extremity functional symptoms; ADL difficulties; functional hand dystonia; work role adaptation

dosing.instructions: Functional task retraining; graded activity progression; sensory retraining for functional sensory loss; workplace and home modifications; assistive device assessment (with goal of weaning)

Physical Rehabilitation (Primary Treatme.monitoring: ADL measures; occupational function; grip strength; dexterity testing

dosing.instructions: Treadmill-based retraining with mirror or video biofeedback; backward walking exercises; dual-task walking (cognitive loading normalizes gait); progressive challenge escalation
dosing.orderSentence: Gait retraining with biofeedback 2-3 sessions/week x 8-12 weeks -

Physical Rehabilitation (Primary Treatme.contraindications: Unable to stand safely; severe cardiovascular instability
Physical Rehabilitation (Primary Treatme.monitoring: Timed 25-foot walk; Berg Balance Scale; fall frequency; gait symmetry measures

Physical Rehabilitation (Primary Treatme.indication: Functional tremor as primary symptom; persistent disabling tremor

doseOptions.orderSentence: Tremor retraining protocol 1-2 sessions/week x 12 weeks -

dosing.instructions: Voluntary movement retraining using distraction; rhythmic entrainment exercises to regain voluntary control; weighted utensil training; progressive relaxation of affected limb; home exercise program

Psychological Treatment.indication: All FMD patients; addresses illness beliefs, symptom attention, avoidance behaviors, perpetuating factors

dosing.instructions: Weekly 50-min sessions; FMD-specific CBT model addressing predisposing, precipitating, and perpetuating factors; cognitive restructuring of illness beliefs; behavioral activation; graded exposure to avoided activities

Psychological Treatment.monitoring: Symptom frequency/severity; functional measures; PHQ-9; GAD-7; treatment engagement

Psychological Treatment.indication: FMD with significant avoidance behavior; excessive symptom monitoring; activity limitation from fear of symptoms

dosing.instructions: Weekly sessions; psychological flexibility; values-based behavior change; defusion from symptom-focused thoughts; mindful awareness of movements without judgment

Psychological Treatment.monitoring: Acceptance and Action Questionnaire (AAQ-II); functional measures; symptom severity

Psychological Treatment.indication: FMD with trauma history; PTSD comorbidity; identifiable traumatic precipitant

doseOptions.orderSentence: EMDR (Eye Movement Desensitization and Reprocessing) 8-12 sessions -

dosing.instructions: Standard EMDR protocol; process traumatic memories contributing to FMD onset or perpetuation; particularly useful when clear temporal link between trauma and movement onset
dosing.orderSentence: EMDR (Eye Movement Desensitization and Reprocessing) 8-12 sessions -

Psychological Treatment.contraindications: Active psychosis; active dissociative disorder (relative -- requires FMD-experienced EMDR therapist); active suicidality
Psychological Treatment.monitoring: PTSD symptom scales (PCL-5); FMD symptom frequency and severity

Psychological Treatment.indication: FMD with anxiety, body hypervigilance, chronic pain comorbidity

doseOptions.orderSentence: Psychodynamic psychotherapy Weekly sessions x 6-12 months -

dosing.instructions: Explore underlying conflicts, emotional processing difficulties, and attachment patterns contributing to FMD; improve affect regulation
dosing.orderSentence: Psychodynamic psychotherapy Weekly sessions x 6-12 months -

Botulinum Toxin Considerations.item: Botulinum toxin (generally NOT recommended for FMD)
Botulinum Toxin Considerations.indication: NOT first-line for functional dystonia; consider ONLY if severe fixed functional dystonia causing contracture risk AND failing rehabilitation AND concomitant organic dystonia cannot be excluded

doseOptions.orderSentence: Botulinum toxin (generally NOT recommended for FMD) Per muscle group IM

dosing.instructions: Specialist decision only; if used, target specific muscles causing contracture risk; limited evidence in functional dystonia; may reinforce biomedical illness model; discuss as adjunct to rehab, not primary treatment
dosing.orderSentence: Botulinum toxin (generally NOT recommended for FMD) Per muscle group IM

Botulinum Toxin Considerations.contraindications: Myasthenia gravis; ALS; pregnancy; infection at injection site
Botulinum Toxin Considerations.monitoring: Muscle weakness; dysphagia (cervical injection); functional outcome; treatment engagement with rehabilitation

Referrals & Consults.item: Neurology (movement disorder specialist with FMD expertise if available) for diagnosis confirmation using positive clinical signs and structured diagnosis delivery
Physiotherapy (FMD-specialized if available) for movement retraining using distraction-based, consensus approach rehabilitation
Clinical psychology (CBT or ACT for FMD) for illness beliefs, avoidance behavior, and perpetuating psychological factors
Psychiatry or neuropsychiatry with FND experience for comorbidity assessment (depression, anxiety, PTSD, personality disorder) and medication management
Occupational therapy for ADL adaptation, upper extremity functional retraining, and graded return to work/role activities
Neurophysiology for surface EMG tremor analysis with accelerometry to provide objective electrophysiologic evidence of functional tremor (entrainment, variability)
Pain management for chronic pain comorbidity refractory to standard pharmacotherapy and psychological treatment
Social work for disability support, vocational rehabilitation referral, family education, and community resource coordination
Neuropsychology for formal cognitive testing if functional cognitive symptoms co-occur with movement disorder
Peer support group (FND Hope, FND Action, local FMD/FND support groups) for normalization, shared experience, and reduced isolation

Patient Instructions.item: Functional movement disorder is a REAL neurological condition -- your movements are genuine and involuntary, not imagined or "put on"
Visit www.neurosymptoms.org for reliable, expert-written information about functional movement disorder (recommended by leading specialists worldwide)
FMD is treatable -- many patients improve significantly with specialized physiotherapy and psychological support; early treatment produces best outcomes
Your positive clinical signs (tremor entrainment, distractibility, Hoover sign) are EVIDENCE of the diagnosis -- ask your neurologist to demonstrate them to you
Specialized physiotherapy is the most effective treatment -- attend all sessions and practice home exercises daily for best results
Avoid excessive medical testing and repeated specialist visits seeking alternative diagnoses; this delays recovery and reinforces symptom focus
Regular physical activity and graded exercise improve outcomes -- avoid prolonged bed rest or complete activity avoidance
Stress, poor sleep, and overexertion can temporarily worsen movements -- pace activities and maintain consistent sleep schedule
Recovery is often gradual with expected setbacks -- a bad day does not mean the diagnosis is wrong or that treatment is failing
Return to ED for symptoms clearly different from your usual functional movements, such as sudden severe headache, fever, new one-sided weakness with facial droop, or loss of consciousness with injury
Do not drive if functional movements or episodes impair safe vehicle operation; discuss driving clearance with your neurologist

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Regular aerobic exercise (30 min, 5x/week) to improve mood, reduce pain perception, and support neuroplasticity underlying movement recovery
Sleep hygiene: consistent bed/wake times 7 days/week, avoid screens 1 hour before bed, limit caffeine after noon to optimize neurological function
Stress management: daily mindfulness practice, breathing exercises, progressive muscle relaxation, or journaling to reduce physiological stress arousal
Activity pacing to avoid boom-bust cycle (overactivity on good days leading to crash and symptom exacerbation on subsequent days)
Limit alcohol consumption as it worsens mood, disrupts sleep, and can exacerbate movement symptoms
Avoid benzodiazepines for functional movement symptoms (ineffective, risk of dependence, may worsen functional neurological symptoms)
Maintain social connections and meaningful activities -- social isolation is a strong perpetuating factor for FMD
Graded return to work or educational activities with occupational therapy support to prevent prolonged disability and deconditioning
Ergonomic assessment of workspace if functional hand tremor or dystonia affects occupational performance

disposition.criteria: Functional movement disorder diagnosis communicated with positive signs demonstrated to patient; patient verbalizes understanding; no acute medical or safety concern; outpatient physiotherapy (FMD-specialized) arranged within 1-2 weeks; psychology referral initiated; family/caregiver education completed; resources provided (neurosymptoms.org); driving safety addressed

Diagnostic uncertainty requiring further evaluation (DaTscan, EMG, video-EEG); severe functional disability preventing safe discharge (unable to ambulate, perform ADLs); acute psychiatric comorbidity requiring stabilization (suicidality, psychosis); recurrent ED visits for functional movement events requiring care coordination and definitive diagnosis

Generally NOT indicated for functional movement disorder; consider ONLY if: iatrogenic complications from inappropriate treatment (sedation-induced respiratory depression, neuroleptic malignant syndrome concern); organic movement disorder emergency (status dystonicus) cannot be excluded pending evaluation

Movement disorder specialist with FMD expertise not available locally; FMD-specialized rehabilitation program referral (tertiary center); neurophysiology (tremor analysis, jerk-locked back-averaging) not available

Severe functional disability (wheelchair-bound, bedbound) from functional movement disorder; failed 12+ weeks of outpatient therapy; good engagement and motivation; multidisciplinary FMD program available at referral center

ALL patients: neurology follow-up within 2-4 weeks for treatment response; physiotherapy initiation within 1-2 weeks; psychology referral within 1 month; PCP follow-up for comorbidity management within 1 month

New symptoms clearly DIFFERENT from established FMD pattern (evaluate for new neurological disease); acute psychiatric emergency; severe functional deterioration failing outpatient treatment; safety concern (falls with injury)
